SEARCH
Package sprouts

Interface Viewable<T>

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the item held by this Val.
All Superinterfaces:
Maybe<T>, Observable, Val<T>
public interface Viewable<T> extends Val<T>, Observable
A read-only live view on a delegated item derived from a Var or Val, which can be observed for changes using Actions registered through the onChange(Channel, Action) method, where the Channel is used to distinguish between changes from different sources (usually application layers like the view model or the view). The API of this is designed to be a null safe wrapper around a single item, which may also be missing (null).

The Channel supplied to the onChange(Channel, Action) method to register an Action callback is expected to be a simple constant, usually one of the From constants like for example From.VIEW_MODEL or From.VIEW. You may fire a change event for a particular channel using the Val.fireChange(Channel) method or in case the property is also a mutable Var, then through the Var.set(Channel, Object).
Note that Var.set(Object) method defaults to the From.VIEW_MODEL channel.

If you no longer need to observe changes on this property, then you can remove the registered Action callback using the Observable.unsubscribe(Subscriber) method (Action is also a Subscriber).

Instances of this are intended to be created from Val and Var properties, using the following methods, among others:

  • Val.view()
  • Val.view()

When they are created from these regular properties, then they are weakly referenced there. You can register change listeners on instances of this, and when you no longer want changes to be propagated to an instance of this, you can drop its reference, and it will be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
See Also:
  • A super type of this class with a read-only API.
  • A mutable property API and subtype of Val.

  • Method Details

    • cast

      static <T> Viewable<T> cast(Val<T> val)
      Casts the given Val instance to a Viewable instance usually with the purpose of registering change listeners on it.
      WARNING: Only call this method in a class constructor with a property which is also a member variable of that class. Otherwise, you are risking memory leaks!

      Regular properties, created from the various factory methods in Val and Var, (may) also implement the Viewable interface internally.
      Although Val and Var do not extend Viewable directly, you may cast them to a Viewable to get access to the Viewable API, and then register change listeners onto it.
      These will be called whenever the item in the Val or Var changes, through the Var::set(Channel, T) method.

      Casting, however, is a bit of a hack, and it is not recommended to use this method anywhere else than in a class constructor, because otherwise it is hard to reason about how many change listeners are registered on a property and what they capture.

      This is problematic because:
      The change listeners registered on the cast property will not be garbage collected automatically. You must remove them manually when no longer needed.

      If you want to protect yourself from memory leaks caused by change listeners, create a Viewable instance through the Val.view() method, and register change listeners on that instance instead.
      The Viewable instance created through the Val.view() method will be garbage collected automatically when no longer needed, and all change listeners registered on it will be removed automatically.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Val instance.
      Parameters:
      val - The Val instance to cast to a Viewable.
      Returns:
      The supplied Val instance cast to a Viewable instance.

    • of

      static <T extends @Nullable Object, U extends @Nullable Object> Viewable<@NonNull T> of(Val<T> first, Val<U> second, BiFunction<T,U,@NonNull T> combiner)
      Creates an observable read-only Viewable property that represents a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function.

      The combiner function takes the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them. The combiner is called to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items in the two properties changes, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see Val.fireChange(Channel)) on either of the two properties.

      Note: The property view does not allow storing null references! So if the combiner function returns a null reference or throws an exception on the first call, a NullPointerException will be thrown. If a null reference is returned on subsequent calls, the view will log a warning and simply retain the last non-null value!

      If you need a composite view that allows null, use the ofNullable(Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The item type of the first property and the returned property.
      U - The type of the second property.
      Parameters:
      first - The first property to be combined.
      second - The second property to be combined.
      combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
      Returns:
      A new Viewable instance which is a live view of the two given properties.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the combiner function returns a null reference when it is first called.

    • ofNullable

      static <T extends @Nullable Object, U extends @Nullable Object> Viewable<@Nullable T> ofNullable(Val<T> first, Val<U> second, BiFunction<T,U,@Nullable T> combiner)
      Creates an observable read-only nullable Viewable property that represents a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function.

      The combiner function takes the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them. The combiner is called to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items in the two properties changes, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see Val.fireChange(Channel)) on either of the two properties.

      Note: The property view does allow storing null references! If the combiner function throws an exception, the view will be set to null.

      If you need a composite view that does not allow null, use the of(Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item of the first property and the returned property.
      U - The type of the second property.
      Parameters:
      first - The first property to be combined.
      second - The second property to be combined.
      combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
      Returns:
      A new nullable Viewable instance which is a live view of the two given properties.

    • of

      static <T extends @Nullable Object, U extends @Nullable Object, R> Viewable<R> of(Class<R> type, Val<T> first, Val<U> second, BiFunction<T,U,R> combiner)
      Creates an observable read-only Viewable property that represents a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function.

      The combiner function takes the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them. The combiner is called to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items in the two properties changes, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see Val.fireChange(Channel)) on either of the two properties.

      Note: The property view does not allow storing null references! So if the combiner function returns a null reference on the first call, a NullPointerException will be thrown. If a null reference is returned on subsequent calls, the view will log a warning and simply retain the last non-null value!

      If you need a composite view that allows null, use the ofNullable(Class, Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the first property.
      U - The type of the second property.
      R - The type of the returned property.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function.
      first - The first property to be combined.
      second - The second property to be combined.
      combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
      Returns:
      A new Viewable instance which is a live view of the two given properties.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the combiner function returns a null reference when it is first called.

    • ofNullable

      static <T extends @Nullable Object, U extends @Nullable Object, R> Viewable<@Nullable R> ofNullable(Class<R> type, Val<T> first, Val<U> second, BiFunction<T,U,@Nullable R> combiner)
      Creates an observable read-only nullable Viewable property that represents a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function.

      The combiner function takes the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them. The combiner is called to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items in the two properties changes, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see Val.fireChange(Channel)) on either of the two properties.

      Note: The property view does allow storing null references! If the combiner function throws an exception, the view will be set to null.

      If you need a composite view that does not allow null items, use the of(Class, Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead of this one.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the first property.
      U - The type of the second property.
      R - The type of the returned property.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function.
      first - The first property to be combined.
      second - The second property to be combined.
      combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
      Returns:
      A new Viewable instance which is a live view of the two given properties.

    • onChange

      Viewable<T> onChange(Channel channel, Action<ValDelegate<T>> action)
      Use this to register an observer lambda for a particular Channel, which will be called whenever the item viewed by this Viewable changes through the Var::set(Channel, T) method. The lambda will receive the current item of this property. The default channel is From.VIEW_MODEL, so if you use the Var::set(T) method then the observer lambdas registered through this method will be called.

      Note that most Exceptions thrown by the supplied Action will be caught and logged in order to avoid disturbing the control flow of the source property, to prevent inconsistent states and unpredictable behavior at runtime.
       However, this does NOT apply to serious Error subtypes, like OutOfMemoryError or StackOverflowError because they represent severe platform errors, which are considered unrecoverable problems that applications should not typically attempt to handle.
      Any InterruptedException is also re-thrown unchanged instead of being logged to comply with how concurrency interruption is designed to work in Java.

      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      action - The lambda which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Var changes.
      Returns:
      The Viewable instance itself.
